document.text: zone defense! at least in the early portion of the season while the team is developing as a cohensive unit. We probably wont have the quickness for man-to-man, notes Tolley. I hope we can work some press into our defense with the zone. Offensively, the Raider ettes will use a combination  of past moves, according to the coach. Sandra Watkins and Beverly Bennett both haVe good outside shots, notes Tolley, Lisa Panned has a good medium-range shot, the coach adds. So the Raiderettes op ponents in the Seminole District will see a team with a slightly different flavor compared with Appomattox teams of the recent past. Commenting on the dis trict competition this sea son, Tolley notes that it is difficult to say before the season, who is going to be strong. On a purely speculative basis, Tolley says that Buckingham, Alta vista ana Jefferson Forest may have strong teams this season.

document.text: Women members of the Virginia delegation to the Demo cratic National Convention entertained at a luncheon last Wednesday in honor of Virginias First Lady, Mrs. Albertis S. Harrison. Mrs. Watkins Abbitt of Appomattox, wife of the Fourth District Congressman and State Central Committee Chairman, is shown above at the head table with Mrs. John Garland Pollard, of Richmond, National Committeewoman. Also present was Mrs. Calvin Robinson, of Appomattox, al ternate delegate-at-large. The luncheon was held at historic Smithville Inn, in Absecon, New Jersey.

document.text: With Virginia voters to elect a Governor, Lieutenant Governor, At torney General and members of the House of Delegates on Tuesday, Nov. 3, political interest is on the up swing here. Appeals are being made to voters by Democratic and Republi can candidates. Representative Watkins M. Ab- bitt, of Appomattox, is state chair man of the campaign for the Demo cratic nominees. George F. Abbitt Jr. is the Democratic chairman for Appomattox County, with Mrs. Cal vin Robinson co-chaifman for the ladies.

document.text: with Miss Mary Elizabeth Paris Mr. William Price with Miss Lucy Smith Mr. Tom Steele with Miss Maude Gregory. The ushers were Messrs. John Rolfe Horsley, B. Watkins Nowlin, John Overton and lampton Steele. The little ribbon- bearers were Jerry Burxe and Jao- queline Atwood Curtis Taylor and Fraces Abbitt Kendall Huuter and Katie Woolridge, and James Stanley and Mattie Sears. Before thp bridal party entered one verse of O Promise Me was softly-sung by Miss Eula Burke ac companied by Mrs. J. R. Atwood. At the conclusion of the solo follow ed the strains of Lohengrins wedding march. The bridesmaids entered from the left wing of tbe church near the altar and passed in front of the altar and down the right aisle. The male attendants entered the left aisle at the front of the church and marched down the right aisle while the bridesmaids passed up the left, forming a semi-circle around the al tar. Following the attendants the groom on the arm of the best man en tered the right aiale, while the bride on the arm of her father, Mr. H. F, Burke, appeared in the left aisle, and proceeded to the alter. The bride was preceded by the maid of honor and followed by her colored maid, Sarah. The bride was attired in a hand some traveling dress of broad-cloth with hat and gloves to matcl. She carried in her hand a small white bible and a white rose-bud. The maid of honor wore a gown of cream crepe cloth, with trimmings of pearls and chiffon, and carried in her hand a large bunch of white chrysanthemums. Tfie bridesmaids wore dresses of white silk mull wearing aigrettes in their hair, and each carrying a white rose iu her hand. After lunching at the brides home they happy pair left on the 130 oclock train for a tour through the West, followed by the best wishes of a host of friends. The groom is a son of Mr. John Steel, of Concord, and bolds the re sponsible position of Agent at Spout Springs of tbe N.  W. By., and is a young man highly esteemed and very popular wherever known. He  has for his young bride a daughter I of Mr. B. F. Burke, cashier of our bank. She is attractive popular, j and highly accomplished. She is  an expert at the telegraph key and Mr. Steele will have a help mate ca pable as be. The presents were  costly and beautiful.

document.text: William Herbert Richardson has been appointed to the Board of Public Welfare for the County of Appomattox.  Richardson, a Pamplin native, was appointed by the Appomattox County Board of Supervisors on March 11 to fill the unexpired term of Tommy Drinkard who resigned because of business obligations. Richardson is a 1938 graduate of Pamplin High School. He served in the United States Army for four years during World W ar II including a tour oI Japan. Working at the Appomattox Hardware Company for ten years, Richardson later worked as a traveling salesman for Watkins-

document.text: will meet on Thursday, October 22 at 645 in the Appomattox County High School cafeteria for its 42nd Year Anniversary Charter Night and Ladies Night. Two charter members. Dr. Clyde G. OBrien and former congressman Watkins M. Ab- bitt are still active in the organization. Woody Landers of Richmond, will entertain the group with tiis magic performance. He is with Westinghouse Credit Corporation as a sales repre sentative. Landers is presently serving his seventh year as territory rice-president of International Brotherhood of Magicians. He is a member of the Society of American Magicians and has performed for his fellow magicians. Coloring contest offered It will soon be that time. You know, when die winds Mow at night with an eerie sound, the leaves rustle in a frightening way and witches take to their brooms for the night.,....itll soon be Hallo ween. Its a special time for children and the TIMES-VIR GINIAN wants to make it - extra special. In this weeks issue of the TIMES-VIRGINIAN is a color ing contest. Children may enter one of five categories, pre school, kindergarten, grades one, two and three. For the first place winner in each category, the TIMES-VIR GINIAN will award a 10.00 first prize and a 5.00 second prize. As evidenced by last years coloring contest held at the Thanksgiving season, Appo mattox County is fall of budding artists. So, get out your colors, you may. use any kind you like. and do your best, t . Contestants are asked t o  take the completed picture to one of the advertisers whose names appear on the page with the ad. The entries will be j picked up by TIMES-VIR GINIAN staff members and judged by art teachers from the local school system. Entries must be completed and - returned to one of the places of business no later than October 30 at 5 p.m. The names of winners in each category will be published in the TIMES-VIRGINIAN for November 4.

She was a member of Appomattox Baptist Temple and an employee of Thomasvide Furniture Corporation. In addition to her parents, she is survived by two sons, William Harvey Hogan and Charles Edward Hogan, both of Appomattox five brothers, Tommy Lee Pugh, Houston, Tex., Grover D. Pugh. Lynchburg, Joel Watkins Pugh, Appomattox, and Harold Walker Pugh mid Robert Guthrie Pugh, both of Spout Spring two sisters, Eugenia Pugh Clay, Gladys, and Nora Pugh Webber. Appomattox. Funeral services were held Sunday at 4 p.m. at Robinson Funerql Home by the Rev. Ronald L. Gallagher. Burial was in Liberty Cemetery. ThcHMsKiaclde Moore Thomas Kinckle Moore, 75, of Route 4, died early Saturday morning in Lynchburg General Hospital. He was born in Appomattox County, a son of, the late Hunter Marshall and Bertha Pajrrish Moore. He was a retired welder for Truck Body Corporation and 4 member of Mt. Comfort United Methodist Church. He is survived by his wife, Estelle Doss Moore four sons. L.C. Moore, Gladstone,- T. Eddie Moore, Appomattox, James A. Moore, Lynchburg and Henry Palmer Moore, Richmond a daughter, Mrs. Herbert Peggy Wood, Madison Heights 13 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Funeral services were conducted Monday at 2 p.m. from Mt. Comfort United Methodist Church by the Rev. David Camden, with burial in the church cemetery. Robinson Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements.

document.text: When Virginia Democrats meet tomorrow in RichmondAppomattox Representative Watkins M. Abbitt will be the party keynote speaker. Abbitt, Fourth District Congress man, will preside at the opening session as temporary chairman, and at about 1230 P. M. will deliver the traditional party keynote ad dress. Appomattox County has 8 votes at the convention, and a number of party stalwarts from here are ex- petced to attend the session. Abbitt was contacted last night by The Times-Virginian, and from Washington, D. C. told our reporter that he would proclaim to the dele gates tomorrow that There is no hope for the South in the Republi can Party. The local leader said that Vir ginia would, of course want a look at the national party platform and notnincs, but th a t the Democratic Party was the traditional party of the South and would be that agalk this presidehtial election year. They didnt outvote us in 1952. They out-proimsed us! Abbitt will tell Virginia Democrats tomorrow. He Thrill call the Eisenhower Ad ministration an Administration of broken promises. Fridays party gathering will be held at the Mosque In Richmond, where the spacious auditorium seats some 5,000 people.. The honor of being the party key noter is such that friends of Mr. Abbitt are delighted that he was accorded such a distinction. In re cent years he has moved up rapidly in the inner councils of the Demo cratic Party, both in Virginia and in Washington. This latest honor is evidence that he is now recognized as the sound leader of a dominant segment of Virginia citizens, and spokesman for majority viewpoints. Nr. Abtyta was asked yesterday by The Times-Virglqian if he plan ned to attend the lflliQnal Conven tion of the Party in Chicago next month. He replied that his name may be on the list of Virginia delegates at large, but that he had not decided whether to attend or permit hie al ternate to represent him. It was considered likefy that Vir ginia will send an uninstructed dele gation to the national convention. There appears to be willinghess in the prospective delegation to accept the nomination of Adlai Stevenson, but there was a solid body of sent- ment for some party recognition of former Governor John S. Battle in a favorite son role.

document.text: When it was necessary to find an outstanding figure in Virginia to take over the campaign of the Democratic nominees for state offices in the No vember general election, the call came to Appomattoxs Watkins M. Abbitt. In our opinion, it was testi mony to the fact that Watt Abbitt knows more practical politics than any other public figure in Virginia. Now that Abbitt is in charge of the campaign, and in view of the short time left before election day, We hope that the powers that be will let him give the orders and run the campaign. If they do, we feel sure that he will win. Abbitt has a knack for winning. If the Democratic nominees go in by substantial majories, we feel major credit should go to Abbitt. He will, in fact, become the most potent leader of the partyand in truth, the party in Virginia is in dire need of new faces.

document.text: West Sec., Mrs. Ora McCoy Treas Mrs. J. C. Webb Pennies for Friendship Treas., Mrs. Dorothy Turner Report er, Mrs. Martha T. Pankey. Mrs. Hudson gave the months demonstration. Final plans for the Christmas Party were made. Mrs. Hudson entertain ed us with games after having served us a complete turkey dinner with all the trimmings including hot rolls and dessert. On December 15 each member with one or more guest gathered in the beautiful decorated home of Mrs. Martha Watkins for our annual Christmas party. Games were played and prizes were won by almost each person present. After a delicious Christmas dinner, we exchanged gifts and each member had brought a toy to help some boy or girl have a happier Christmas. We were dismissed with plans to meet with Mrs. Mary West on January 24, 1973 at 7 p.m. Your Reporter, M. Pankey

document.text: Well, well, lets see vhat there is to chronicle tonight? Whither, vaulted columnar ver nacular?    First, J. H. Cheatham had a birthday yesterday. He was down on the streets before 7 oclock doffing his sombrero in token of 68 birthdays. Yas sah. And Len Smith and W. M. Hancock had birthdays togeth er Chooseday . . . 69 I do bow- lieve.    Then, theres that fishing party of Tuesday. Our Col. Joel, E. T. Mitc.hell, J. H. OBrien, aided and abetted to- wit, wherewithal and whereas by Watkins Abbitt, garnered their earthworms and, hied away to Horseleys Pond, wherever that is. The Col. mussed up his shirt front with a sun perch. Cope teste, Father Darkleaf, et cafeteria.    Nfurthermore, theres the case of the right Rev. Lee. Hes dean of the colored parsons in Roanoke. Happened to be here attending court last week and when a pair of matrimonial- bound colored folks applied for a license said Rev. Lee was called in to do the honors right in the clerks office. Vo-do-de- o-do.    Theres something, it might be chronicled, whimsical about a bathrobe. Father Darkleafs favorite is one used for eleven years. Had several given me since I got thatbut my bones and joints dont feel right in em.    And orchids to Mother Bright- leaf. Shes twenty-seven cents on the blue inc side of our bud get for June. And keeps her ledg r like a veteran, she does. And I like the fare better than Delmonicos.    Oh yes, I forgot, the colored couples names were Perry Nathenial Brown and Annie Lee Mins. Thats the sort of a reporter I am .   and the parsons initials are W. E., since Im being downright accurate.    And folks, Im warning you, Mather Brightleaf is hot after back subscribers. And when I told her about the way folks wouldnt Subscribe for them selves but borrowed. their neighbors paper, she turned up her nose, she did and said, The stingy things. One subscriber on one of the routes this week said he had to put up with four families borrowing his Times- - Virginian. Scallions and ashes.    George Peery no doubt real izes hes gonna be the next governor, but hes taking no chances. Has a plaque on hijP office wall containing four-leaf  clovers, horse-shoes and a rab bits foot.    Lots of suckers will bet on on the big prize fight tonight. The only thing I ever bet on was when I called Mother Brightleafs bet that my mother didnt serve oatmeal for break fast. Proved it too, by heck.

Abbitt for renomination and re-election to Congress from the Fourth District, introduced by Calvin Robinson and one endorsing the record of United States Senator Harry F. Byrd, in troduced by C. W. document.text: We are sorry our old corres pondent has gone to Florida, but hope she will return with the Robins next spring. We are sorry to hear the Hat cher families are going to leave our neighborhood.  Mr- and Mrs. A. B. Abbitt, of Newport News, visited their country home hereThanksgi vi ng. Miss Frances Abbitt, teacher of Roanoke, and Mr. Bernard Abbitt, of Roanoke, were the quests of their parents here Taanksgiving. Mr. Walsh Riley killed an 18 pound gobbler on Thanksgiving Oay. Rev. S. B. Tucker, wife and little son, are visiting Ore Batiks for the past week. We are sorry to hear of the continued illness of Mrs. Robert Allen Covington.  Mr. Lewis Turnes and Mrs. G R. Nunley were quietly married on the 20th. Mr. George and Watkins Ab bitt. of Richmond College were at home for Thanksgiving. Mr. Jud Kinney is driving new car. Mr. C. L. Coleman had the misfortune to break his wrist while working on the highway last week, but is getting along nicely. Misses Roberta and Ethel Cole man were at home for the holi day. Mr. Thomas Harvey is very ill at this writing. We are glad to hear Mr. R. D. Abbitt is somewhat better. Times are getting tight we are going to explore a new cave soon, we will tell you more about it when we get lined up. We see a young man from our neighborhood going to Anderson- ville mighty often these days. Thanksgiving was enjo fed by everybody in this neighborhood News is like money nowadays, getting scarce.

document.text: Watkins M. AhbUt, Jr., has been appointed by Gov, Charles S. Robb to the Uranium Administrative Group, a committee formed to study the possible Impact of uranium minirig and milling in Virginia. ,The Uranium Adm inistrative Group is comprised of representa tive of the states Water Control Board, Board of Health, Air Pollution Control Board, Depart- ment of Conservation arid Economic Development, Department of Agri culture and Consumer .Services, and, Division offrtckistrial Development.  amelia Prindiville, administrator of the Council on the Environment, is alsoa member of the group, as are at-large representatives from Pitt sylvania and Halifax Counties. The Uranium Administrative Group was1 established by Senate Bill 155, introduced by Sen. Danny Bird, who is chairman of the Coal and Energy Commission. A uranium subcommittee, formed in 1981 to conduct research for the Cool and Energy Commission, has determined with the assistance of consultants that the health risks involved in uranium mining and milling are limited, if the proper operating procedures and manage ment policies are established ana enforced. The subcommittee recommended that further research be conducted to determine if the benefits from uranium operations in Virginia

Abbitt, representative of the Fourth Congressional District, I praised farming as a life work in his address before the 1953 Father-Son Banquet of the Appomattox Chapter, Future Farmers of America here on Friday night. Congressman Abbitt reviewed agri cultural progress in southern Vir ginia during the present century and stressed particularly the improve ment that has been made in farm family living. Farm families no longer need to do without the con veniences city people enjoy, he said. Jack Stratton, president, served as toastmaster for the banquet, attend ed by nearly 100 Future Farmers, their fathers and invited guests. The welcome address was made by Ben. jamin Beasley. document.text: Watkins M. Abbitt, Representa tive from the Fourth Congressional District, recently co-sponsored a bill aimed at curbing the high-handed manner in which some federal judges have arrogated unto them selves authority that they never had. The circumstances behind the bill come from thé strife-torn town of Clinton, Tenn., where a federal judge issued an injunction against people in general, including those not a party to any legal proceed ings. Abbitt and his co-sponcor, Con gressman Flynt, of Georgia, have aimed the bill to specify the powers of the court , in contempt proceed ing. Abbitt said, Briefly the bill will limit the power of Federal judges to the issuing of injunctions and will guarantee to the citizens of this counltry a trial by jury in all con tempt proceedings other than mis behavior of any person in the pres ence of the court or so near there to as to obstruct the administration of justice and misbehavior of any of the officers of the court in their official transactions. The bill also provides certain safeguards as to who is guilty of contempt. Abbitt said in presenting the bill, It has become necessary that the Congress do something to protect the rights,4 privileges, and freedoms of the citizens of this country. We have seen some of the judiciary arrogate unto themselves authority that they never had. They have usurped power never given them by the Constitution or the tow of the tond.

document.text: Watkins M. Abbitt. Others are giving their OK to be on the program, and Civic Chorus president Horace Folks says that response to the idea of the program has been heart warming. Folks say there has been some confusion as to the wearing of Civil War Period dress. He says that this is strict ly optional  and that everyone is welcome to come, whether costumed or not. Therell be singing by audience and chorus and a sparkling Dixie finale to make it an evening well worth remembering.

document.text: Watkins M. Abbitt, Member of Congress, retired, is shown above as he spoke Monday evening to a group of citizens interested in the Scouting Program in Appomattox County, thus kicking-off the Boy Scout Finance Campaign. The goal for Appomattox County is 2300.00, based on a rate of 20.00 per Boy Scout of which there are 130 in Appomattox County. , Now more than ever boys need training, and the training they get as active members of Cub Scouts and Boy Scouts is hard to beat. Your contributions will be appreciated. You can mail in donations to Watkins M. Abbitt, Chairman Boy Scout Finance Campaign, or to Mr. Ivey Holland, Appomattox, Va. 24522. The Appomattox County Lions will also be soliciting funds for scouting.

document.text: Watkins M. Abbitt, Jr. son of Rep. and Mrs. W. M. Abbitt, is spending this week in Miami Beach, Florida, where he is at tending the Democratic Nation al Convention.
